title: Riots balance team is slacking
body:
This is my opinion. I realize they work hard, but they work hard in all the wrong ways. The game is no longer strategy based, its just a huge clusterfuck of stat checking at this point. It is honestly getting to a point where the game is not enjoyable. 

again, just my opinion.

replies.body:
I mean, claiming they're even working hard at this point is a stretch given how we only have the game quality as a base to gauge their "success."

And we all see how the game's "quality" is doing now don't we?

They should focus on a few things that are destroying the game. 
Snowballing: it seems that once someone has a couple of kills the game is nearly almost over. There is not enough time to build up, play safe, turtle, and comeback. 
Damage Creep: people claim it doesn't exist and riot seems to just disregard it entirely, but when team fights are over in under 15 seconds, and bruisers and supports are 100-0% people, there is a problem. There needs to be an overall damage adjustment especially to base damage, this forces people to actually **build** damage items to do damage instead of stacking health and doing the same a different champ who build solely damage. Also champs that relie on DOT are garbage right now.. either get rid of DoT or tone back the burst. Why would anyone pick {{champion:17}} {{champion:27}}  when they could play {{champion:45}} {{champion:63}} 
Turrets: for the love of the rift, turrets need a buff. They do not need more health, but they need to do %health damage effected by armor. you should simply not be able to 1v1 someone under their own turret and then walk away with above 75% health. This is some champs only method of defense until they hit mid game, and turrets are nothing more then confetti shooters made out of candle wax at this point.
 Invulnerability: There is little more annoying than playing against a {{champion:105}}  {{champion:2}} and having your abilities be meaningless because he is on his troll pole or ...simply immune to all cc. 
True damage: There should simply not be any true damage. The point of building items is to itemize against your enemies so that you are better equipped, true damage toxic to the game and cannot be balanced. 
Items: there needs to be more options for itemization, especially on the ap side. I dont know why, but it feels like ad items are more efficient and have more options. {{item:3916}} {{item:3020}} {{item:3135}}  vs {{item:3147}} {{item:3814}} {{item:3124}} {{item:3035}} {{item:3036}} {{item:3033}} {{item:3071}} .. get the idea
Most importantly is Jungle: Jungle needs to take longer to clear camps early on for many people. I get that it is boring to sit in the jungle and farm, but its so toxic having the jungle be able to gank levels 1-4 because they already cleared most of the camps. Jungles should also have to invest more in their jungle items, they should get more benefits from them, but they should cost more. this would force them to commit to a jungle build path instead of rushing core items early on.

True damage SHOULD exist, but not in large access or quantities. Currently there are more champs with true damage (and a rune that gives it to melee's for free for as long as they can auto a target) now compared to when Morrello slammed the hammer on true damage and changed a bunch of champs to not have it for the sake of making the stat balanced for specific situations.

Did stat checking enter the lexicon because Riot used the term as a justification for the Aatrox rework?


LoL is chock full of RPG elements, thus stats.  Though skills such as decision-making, juking, etc... will play a part in LoL, at some point stats are going to determine the outcome (power curve disadvantages, item spikes, etc...).


(would be nice though if the ttk was greater than .5s again and poking didn't chunk)

It's a common term not unique to League/Riot but in this case it was used incorrectly. It's supposed to talk about old RPGs or poorly designed games where the victory condition is mostly determined not by skill (Using the right spells/abilities) or loadout (Taking certain resistance gear into a fight vs. a specific damage type.) but just who has the bigger number and hits harder.

Said in another comment but old Aatrox/Kayle were pretty good examples of stat-checking as they just kinda jump/slow you and then hit you with the hopes that you die.
Literally Jax, compounded by Conqueror.

Jax is pretty stat-check-y yeah. He's got SOMETHING with his E but most of the time he's just jumping on you and beating your face in. Some other examples would be stuff like Tryn or Nasus who just sit on top of you and beat your face in with PaCs.

Aatrox had his knockup and his slow, only his W and R were stat-checky. Jax literally says fuck your auto attacks and then stuns you, and kills you before the 1 second stun is over. Otherwise, he kills you right after or doesn't fight you at all. It's really unfun.
if that's your definition of stat checking then what is kled, a fairly new champion, by your definition of "jump/slow you and then hit you with the hopes that you die"?

Sorta. 

He's fairly simple but he still has grab the bear trap as well as close the distance, plus the HP management and the battle between "Stand/Fight" vs. "Flee/Run" when you're dismounted. It's not much, yeah, but it's something.

You can literally dodge Aatrox's Q and E. That's the opposite idea of stat checking by definition.

Also... AD carries would be considered more of a stat check by that definition.

I feel like they are just too afraid of the "invisible power". For example while I do enjoy the new Taric and I really didn't play the old Taric they changed him because of "invisible power". They changed Runes and masteries from "invisible power" to "stuff that you notice". However, now they are starting to realize that the "invisible power" is actually necessary and they're putting flat stats back into the mastery tree. 

It is literally WAY easier to balance the game if you're working off of actual numbers instead of flashy abilities that you may or may not use to their fullest extent. 

They seriously make their jobs way too difficult with things like akali and galio rework, new champions like zoe.  Like the balancing nightmare they have where it goes from 1 shotting people with Q to almost unplayable with just some slight adjustments. Keep it simple, you aren't Leonardo and this isn't the Sistine Chapel. This is everyman's chapel the one that 90% of the world walks into. If you go for Sistine Chapel without the help of Leonardo Da Vinci you end up with a disaster.
It certainly doesnt help that the team that gets a slight lead, turns that into a commanding lead with no extra effort thanks to first tower gold and the ridiculous stats that items give.

> its just a huge clusterfuck of stat checking at this point.

Yeah, that's...not quite how stat-checking works. Like at all.

As an example of a stat-check, look at something like Kayle or old Aatrox. Essentially they get close to you, then pull out a spreadsheet and put on the business glasses. Then they check to see how the stats compare. If they had higher ones, they win. ADCs can also be guilty of this in some cases as a lot of their power is in unavoidable autos.

A clusterfuck of statchecking would be:

* Lots of point-and-click champions are absurdly strong. (Garen, Volibear, Fiddlesticks, etc.)
* The benefit of playing a non-stat-check (Skillshots, small aoes, etc) isn't high enough to justify playing them.
* Mechanically simple champs are best. Y'know: Tanks. 

And yeah, the popular argument is "GAME NOT STRATEGY NO MORE" (which I still disagree with) but even a champion that boards hates like Zed or Yasuo still have avenues to fuck up in escape, skillshots or otherwise. Overall, game's not as stat-check-y as it was earlier. Argue the other stuff at your leisure.

Well they _think_ they like the idea of strategy based. Until they realize that it requires work and a lot of time practicing with the exact same teammates.

Sort of.

Main problem people have with strategy now is that it actually matters more than ever, as even a small mistake nets you a huge punish. It's also why tank metas are preferred: Mistakes mean very little in tank metas because a "punish" is generally a small bit of damage and you're never hit as hard for fucking up as you are in a meta like this. Major fuck-ups still exist in tank metas (Diving 1v5) but overall they're much more rare.

A tank meta is a sumo match where both players are trying to shove each other off a small platform while a damage meta is two shaolin monks standing on soda-can-sized poles trying to knock each other off. Yeah, both have similar goals but one is much less leniant with mistakes and requires you to always be on the top of your game while the other allows you to make a LOT of errors before you get knocked out of the arena.
